text: rattle new toys baby Ollie his parents
Jessica and Michael Neela's we're hoping
they'd also have a new home in time for
his arrival but one major financial
obstacle stands in their way I'm looking
at probably paying my loans until my
son's in college and he was born in
November Michael is a high school
science teacher and spends nearly half
his monthly take-home pay on his student
loans which total $64,000 the family's
high level of debt means they can't
borrow money for a house the mortgage
broker told me in no uncertain terms
that he couldn't do anything for me as
long as I had my student loan debt which
was a complete shock considering I
worked through college I had academic
scholarship I thought I did everything
right I I got an education to be
successful to better myself and the
reality of it is is I'm worse off than
my peers the US housing market an
important part of the American economy
shows signs of recovering after a
difficult recession but slowly one of
the reasons the recovery is so slow is
that first-time buyers aren't snapping
up properties like this they've
historically been the bedrock of the US
housing market accounting for some 40
percent of total sales that figure has
now fallen to just 30 percent and
student loan debt is one of the key
things holding younger people back from
buying their first home the cost of
going to college has gone up
substantially in recent years mainly
because of increases and tuition fees
student loans are now the second biggest
type of consumer debt in America after
mortgages overtaking car loans and
credit card borrowing the total amount
of student debt nationwide is almost
quadrupled in the last ten years
ballooning from two hundred and fifty
three billion dollars in 2003 to over a
trillion dollars by the end of 2013
student loan debt is without question
this big ticking time bomb that's
impacting the marketplace it translates
to the entire economy and could dampen
the the pace of the of the US economic
from where we were hoping it would go
without this this overhang of a trillion
dollars of debt hanging on these young
people's backs for Michael Millis that
debt makes it hard sometimes just to
provide for his family although he hopes
his college education will be worth the
investment in the long term the dream of
home ownership seems a very long way off
Beth McLeod BBC News Philadelphia
